Indeed, know that every human is ignorant of the faults of his own soul [nafs]. If he strives against his soul [nafs] with the slightest striving, to the point of abandoning the gross acts of disobedience, he may imagine of himself that he has refined his soul [nafs] and beautified his character [khuluq] and become free of the need for striving. Therefore, it is necessary to clarify the sign of a beautiful character [khuluq]. For indeed, a beautiful character [khuluq] is faith [iman], and an ugly character [khuluq] is hypocrisy [nifaq]. And Allah, the Exalted, has mentioned the attributes of the believers [mu'minun] and the hypocrites [munafiqun] in His Book, and they are, in their totality, the fruit of a beautiful character [khuluq] and an ugly character [khuluq]. So let us present a summary of that, so that you may know the sign of a beautiful character [khuluq]. Allah, the Exalted, says: "Indeed, successful are the believers [mu'minun], those who are in their prayer humbly submissive [khashi'un], and those who turn away from idle talk [laghw]" up to His saying: "Those are the inheritors." Whoever is uncertain about his own state, let him present himself against these verses. The presence of all these attributes is a sign of a beautiful character [khuluq], and the absence of all of them is a sign of an ugly character [khuluq]. And the presence of some of them without others indicates [the presence of] some without others. So let him occupy himself with attaining what he lacks and preserving what he has found.

Indeed, I have created Adam, peace be upon him, with My Hand [yad], and I wrote the Torah with My Hand, and I planted Paradise [al-jannah] with My Hand. Then I said to it, 'Speak,' and it said: **"Indeed, the believers have attained success [qad aflaha al-mu'minun]."** These are the attributes [sifat] of Paradise which We have mentioned in summary, then We have conveyed them in detail. And indeed, Al-Hasan Al-Basri, may God have mercy upon him, mentioned them all, saying: Indeed, its pomegranates are like water-skins, and indeed its rivers are of water [ma'] that is not stagnant, and rivers of milk [laban] whose taste has not changed, and rivers of honey [asal] purified, not purified by men. And indeed, in it is wine [khamr], a delight for the drinkers, which does not befuddle the minds nor cause headaches. And indeed, in it is what no eye has seen, no ear has heard, and what has not occurred to the heart [qalb] of any human. They are kings, living in comfort, sons of thirty-three, in one age. Their height is sixty cubits in the sky, with kohl, beardless, smooth-skinned. They are secure from the punishment, and the Abode [al-dar] is at peace with them. And indeed, its rivers flow over pebbles of ruby and chrysolite. And indeed, its roots, its palm trees, and its vines are of pearl, and its fruitsâ€”none knows their knowledge [ilm] except God, the Exalted. And indeed, its fragrance is found from a distance of five hundred years' journey. And indeed, for them in it are horses and camels, swift, their saddles and bridles and saddles of ruby. They visit one another in it, and their spouses are the wide-eyed maidens [al-hur al-'in], as if they were hidden pearls. And indeed, a woman takes seventy garments between her two fingers and wears them, and the marrow of her shin is seen from behind those seventy garments. God has purified the characters [al-akhlaq] from evil and the bodies from death. They do not blow their noses in it, nor do they urinate, nor do they defecate. It is only a belch and a sweat of musk. Their provision [rizq] is in it morning and evening. Behold, there is no night; morning comes upon evening and evening comes upon morning. And indeed, the last to enter Paradise [al-jannah] and the lowest in rank, sight [basar] and dominion [mulk] will be extended for him.

ğŸ“– Vol 1: Secrets of Prayer
Indeed, then He concluded the attributes of the successful ones with prayer as well, saying, the Most High: **"And those who are over their prayers [salawat] vigilant [yuhafidhun]."** As for the prayer of the heedless, it is a peril, unless Allah envelops them with His mercy [rahma], and the mercy is vast, and the generosity is overflowing. So we ask Allah to envelop us with His mercy and to immerse us with His forgiveness, for we have no means except the confession of incapacity to fulfill obedience to Him. And know that purifying the prayer [salah] from defects, and making it sincere [ikhlas] for the Countenance of Allah, the Mighty and Majestic, and performing it with the inward conditions we mentionedâ€”of humility [khushu'], reverence [ta'zim], and shame [haya']â€”is a cause for the occurrence of lights [anwar] in the heart [qalb]. Those lights become keys to the sciences of unveiling [mukashafa]. The allies of Allah [awliya'], those unveiled to the dominion [malakut] of the heavens and the earth and the secrets of Lordship, are only unveiled during prayer, especially in prostration [sujud], for the servant draws near to his Lord, the Mighty and Majestic, through prostration. And for that reason, Allah, the Most High, said: **"And prostrate and draw near."** And the unveiling [mukashafa] for every person praying is only according to the measure of his clarity from the impurities of the world [dunya], and that differs in strength and weakness, in scarcity and abundance, and in clarity and obscurityâ€”until the thing itself is unveiled to some of them, and to some of them the thing is unveiled by its likeness, just as the world [dunya] was unveiled to some of them in the form of a carcass, and Satan in the form of a dog crouching upon it, calling to it. And it also differs according to what is in the unveiling: for some of them, His attributes [sifat] and His majesty [jalal] are unveiled; for some, His actions; and for some, the subtleties of the sciences of spiritual transaction [mu'amala]. And the specification of those meanings in every moment has hidden causes beyond enumeration. The most fitting of them is aspiration [himma], for when it is directed to a specific thing, that thing is most deserving of being unveiled. And since these matters only appear in polished mirrors, and all mirrors were rusty, guidance [hidaya] was veiled from themâ€”not due to stinginess from the side of the Bestower of guidance, but due to the foulness of accumulated rust upon the place where guidance is received. Tongues hastened to deny such things, for nature is created to deny what is not present. If the fetus had intellect, it would deny the possibility of a human existing in the expanse of the air. And if the child had discernment, he might perhaps deny what the people of intellect claim to perceive of the dominion [malakut] of the heavens and the earth. And thus is man in every stage; he almost denies what...

Indeed, Allah the Almighty has said: "Indeed, the believers have succeeded [qad aflaha al-mu'minun] â€“ those who are in their prayer humbly submissive [khashi'un]." a.ihya:
Ihya 'Ulum al-Din Commentary

Vol 2: Etiquette of Marriage
Indeed, We created the human being [al-insan] from an extract of clay [tin]. Then We placed him as a drop of sperm [nutfah] in a firm resting place [qararin makin]. Then We made the sperm-drop into a clinging clot [alaqah], and We made the clot into a lump [mudghah], and We made the lump into bones [izam], and We clothed the bones with flesh [lahm]; then We brought him into being as another creation. So blessed is Allah, the best of creators. (Quran 23:12-14) And He reminds you that you were created from a base fluid [nutfah qadhirah]. He said: "Destroyed is man; how ungrateful he is! From what thing did He create him? From a sperm-drop [nutfah] He created him and destined for him; then He made the way easy for him; then He causes him to die and be buried; then when He wills, He will resurrect him." (80:17-22) And He, the Exalted, said: "And among His signs is that He created you from dust [turab], then, at once, you are human beings dispersing [tansharun]." (30:20) And He, the Exalted, said: "Was he not a sperm-drop [nutfah] of semen emitted [mani yumna]? Then he was a clinging clot [alaqah], and He created [fakhalaqa] and proportioned [fasawwa]." (75:37-38) And He, the Exalted, said: "Did We not create you from a despised water [ma'in mahin]? Then We placed it in a firm resting place [qararin makin], for a known extent [qadar ma'lum]." (77:20-22) And He said: "Does man not consider that We created him from a sperm-drop [nutfah]? And at once he is a clear adversary [khasim mubin]." (36:77) And He said: "We created the human being from a sperm-drop mixed [nutfah amshaj]." (76:2) Then He mentioned how He made the sperm-drop into a clinging clot [alaqah], and the clot into a lump [mudghah], and the lump into bones [izam]. The repeated mention of the sperm-drop [nutfah] in the Mighty Book is not merely to hear its word and neglect reflection upon its meaning. So look now at the sperm-drop [nutfah]â€”it is a droplet of base, impure water. If it were left for an hour for the air to strike it, it would spoil and become foul. How did the Lord of lords extract it from the loins and ribs? How did He bring together the male and the female and cast affection [ulfah] and love [mahabbah] into their hearts [qulub]? How did He lead them by the chain of love [mahabbah] and desire [shahwah] to union? How did He extract the sperm-drop [nutfah] from the man by the movement of intercourse? How did He draw the menstrual blood from the depths of the veins and gather it in the womb? Then how did He create the child from the sperm-drop [nutfah] and nourish it with the water of menstruation until it grew, developed, and became large? And how did He make the sperm-drop [nutfah], which is white and shining, into a red clinging clot [alaqah]? Then how did He make it into a lump [mudghah]? Then how did He divide the parts of the sperm-drop [nutfah], which are equal and similar, into bones [izam], nerves [a'sab], veins [urouq], tendons [awtar], and flesh [lahm]? Then how did He construct from the flesh [luhum], nerves [a'sab], and veins [urouq] the apparent limbs [a'da']: the roundness of the head, the aperture for hearing, sight, the nose, the mouth, and all the other openings? Then He extended the hand and the leg and divided their ends into fingers [asabi'], and divided the fingers into fingertips [anamil]. Then how did He construct the internal organs [a'da']: the heart [qalb], the stomach [ma'idah], the liver [kabid], the spleen [tihal], the lung [ri'ah], the womb [rahim], the bladder [mathanah], and the intestines [am'a']â€”each one with a specific form [shakl makhsus] and a specific measure [miqdar makhsus] for a specific function [amal makhsus]? Then how did He divide each one of these organs into other divisions? He constructed the eye from seven layers [tabaqat]; for each layer is a specific attribute [wasf makhsus] and a specific form [hai'ah makhsus]. If a single layer from them were missing, or an attribute from its attributes were removed, the eye would be incapacitated from sight [ibsar]. If we were to begin describing the wonders [aja'ib] and signs [ayat] contained in each single one of these organs, lifetimes would be exhausted in it. So look now at the bones [izam]â€”they are solid, strong bodies. How did He create them from a weak, delicate sperm-drop [nutfah]? Then He made them the framework [qiwam] for the body and its support [amad]. Then He proportioned them with different measures [maqadir] and different forms [ashkal]: among them is small and large, long and round, hollow and solid, broad and delicate. And since the human being is in need of movement with his entire body and with some of his limbs [a'da'], and is in need of moving about for his needs, He did not make his bone a single bone, but rather many bones [izam] between which are joints [mafasil] so that movement is facilitated by them. And He proportioned the form [shakl] of each one in accordance with the movement required by it. Then He connected their joints and bound some of them to others with tendons [awtar] which He caused to grow from one end of the bone and attached it to the other bone.

Indeed, in summary, whoever considers it possible that he may be wretched [shaqiyy] with Allah, and that the decree [qada'] in pre-eternity [al-azal] has preceded concerning his wretchedness, has no way to be arrogant [yata-kabbar] in any state whatsoever. Yes, if fear [khawf] overcomes him, he sees everyone as better than himself, and that is the virtue [al-fadilah]. As it is narrated that an ascetic ['abid] took refuge in a mountain, and it was said to him in a dream: "Go to so-and-so the cobbler [al-iskaff] and ask him to supplicate for you." So he went to him and asked him about his practice ['amal], and he informed him that he fasts the day, earns a living, gives charity [yata-saddaq], and feeds his family with some of it. The ascetic returned saying: "This is indeed good, but it is not like being free for the worship of Allah." Then he came in a second dream and it was said to him: "Go to so-and-so the cobbler and say to him: 'What is this pallor [al-saffar] on your face?'" So he went to him and asked him. He said to him: "I have not seen anyone from the people except that it occurs to me: that he will be saved [yanju] and I will be destroyed [ahlak]." The ascetic said: "By this." And what indicates the virtue of this characteristic is His saying, the Most High: "Indeed, those who are apprehensive [mushfiqun] from fear [khashya] of their Lord..." So arrogance [al-kibr] is the proof of feeling secure [al-amn], and feeling secure [al-amn] is destructive [muhlik]. And humility [al-tawadu'] is the proof of fear [al-khawf], and it is felicitous [musa'id]. And We charge no soul except [with that within] its capacity, and with Us is a record which speaks with truth; and they will not be wronged.

Do not cry out today. Indeed, by Us you will not be helped.
My verses had already been recited to you, but you were turning back on your heels
In arrogance regarding it, conversing by night, speaking evil.
Then have they not reflected over the Qur'an, or has there come to them that which had not come to their forefathers?
Or did they not know their Messenger, so they are toward him disacknowledging?
Or do they say, "In him is madness?" Rather, he brought them the truth, but most of them, to the truth, are averse.

But if the Truth had followed their inclinations, the heavens and the earth and whoever is in them would have been ruined. Rather, We have brought them their message, but they, from their message, are turning away.
Or do you, [O Muhammad], ask them for payment? But the reward of your Lord is best, and He is the best of providers.
And indeed, you invite them to a straight path.
But indeed, those who do not believe in the Hereafter are deviating from the path.
And even if We gave them mercy and removed what was upon them of affliction, they would persist in their transgression, wandering blindly.
And We had gripped them with suffering [as a warning], but they did not yield to their Lord, nor did they humbly supplicate, [and will continue thus]
Until when We have opened before them a door of severe punishment, immediately they will be therein in despair.
And it is He who produced for you hearing and vision and hearts; little are you grateful.
And it is He who has multiplied you throughout the earth, and to Him you will be gathered.
And it is He who gives life and causes death, and His is the alternation of the night and the day. Then will you not reason?
Rather, they say like what the former peoples said.
They said, "When we have died and become dust and bones, are we indeed to be resurrected?
We have been promised this, we and our forefathers, before; this is not but legends of the former peoples."
Say, [O Muhammad], "To whom belongs the earth and whoever is in it, if you should know?"
They will say, "To Allah." Say, "Then will you not remember?"
Say, "Who is Lord of the seven heavens and Lord of the Great Throne?"
They will say, "[They belong] to Allah." Say, "Then will you not fear Him?"
Say, "In whose hand is the realm of all things - and He protects while none can protect against Him - if you should know?"
They will say, "[All belongs] to Allah." Say, "Then how are you deluded?"
Rather, We have brought them the truth, and indeed they are liars.

Allah has not taken any son, nor has there ever been with Him any deity. [If there had been], then each deity would have taken what it created, and some of them would have sought to overcome others. Exalted is Allah above what they describe [concerning Him].
